resources.title: Asteroid Knowledge Hub
resources.intro_text: Near-Earth Objects (NEOs) are comets and asteroids that have been nudged by the gravitational attraction of nearby planets into orbits that allow them to enter the Earth's neighborhood.

terms.ne_def: An asteroid or comet with a perihelion distance less than 1.3 astronomical units.
terms.pha_def: An asteroid with a minimum orbit intersection distance of 0.05 AU or less and an absolute magnitude of 22.0 or less.
terms.au_def: The average distance between the Earth and the Sun, approximately 150 million kilometers.
terms.albedo_def: A measure of the reflectivity of the asteroid's surface.
terms.magnitude_def: A measure of the intrinsic brightness of a celestial object.

home.hero_desc: Real-time tracking of Near-Earth Objects (NEOs) using NASA's NeoWs API. Analyze trajectories, assess impact risks, and secure our future.
home.live_feed_desc: Direct integration with the Jet Propulsion Laboratory (JPL) to provide up-to-the-second data on approaching asteroids.
home.risk_analysis_desc: Advanced algorithms classify objects based on estimated diameter, velocity, and miss distance to identify potential hazards.
home.watchlist_desc: Create an account to track specific objects of interest and receive alerts if their trajectory becomes threatening.

login.already_have_account: Already have an account? Sign In
login.policy_agreement: By accessing this system, you agree to the NASA Open Data Policy & Security Protocols.
